definition: a physical quantity which has magnitude only
a physical quantity which has both magnitude and direction
the rate of change of velocity
the distance measured in a straight line in a specified direction
total length travelled by a body regardless of the direction of motion
the distance traveled per unit time
the rate of change of displacement
a region in which a mass experiences a force due to gravitational attraction
gravitational force per unit mass placed at that point
a measure of the amount of matter in a body
the force of gravity acting on a body
A body will remain in its state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by a resultant force.

The resultant force acting on an object of a constant mass is the product of the mass and acceleration of the object. The object accelerates in the direction of the resultant force. Fres = ma F A a B Considering entire system, F = (mA + mB)a a a
If body A exerts a force on body B, then body B exerts an equal and opposite force on body A.
the point through which the entire weight of a body appears to act for any orientation of the object
the product of the force and the perpendicular distance between the axis of rotation and the line of action of the force.
the ability of an object to return to its original position after it has been displaced slightly
when a system experiences no resultant force and no resultant torque
the amount of force acting perpendicularly on per unit area. P = F/A
the ratio of useful energy output to the total energy input
rate of energy transfer
Energy cannot be created or destroyed but can be transferred from one store to another. The total energy of an isolated system remains constant.
the product of force and the distance moved in the direction of the force
the ratio of speed of light in vacuum and in the medium
the angle of incidence in a medium with a higher refractive index for which the angle of refraction in the medium with a lower refractive index is 90¡.
The distance between the optical centre and focal point

phenomenon that occurs when a light ray traveling from a medium with a higher refractive index to a medium with a lower refractive index is completely reflected back into the denser medium. This occurs when the incident angle is larger than the critical angle.
the magnitude of maximum displacement of the particle from its equilibrium position.
the number of complete waves produce per unit time
waves in which the displacement of the particles of the medium is parallel to the direction of energy transfer.
the time for a particle in the wave to complete one cycle of vibration
waves in which the displacement of the particles of the medium is perpendicular to the direction of the direction of energy transfer
the distance a wave travels per unit
an imaginary line or surface that joins points of a wave that are in phase.
the shortest distance between 2 points which are vibrating in phase.
a region in which an electric charge experiences an electric force.
the rate of flow of charge
the work done by a source in driving a unit charge around a complete circuit

term: Potential difference across an electrical device
definition: the work done per unit charge in driving chargfes through a component
the ratio of the potential difference across the component to the current flowing through it
a safety device connected to the live wire which switches off the electrical supply when a excessive current flows through it
two layers of protection to prevent users from coming into contact with live electrical parts, eliminating the need for an earth connection
wire providing a path for electrical current to flow safely into the ground in case of a fault, preventing the appliance's exterior from becoming live and reducing the risk of electric shock.
a safety device connected to the live wire and is designed to melt/break, thus creating an open circuit, when the current passing through it exceeds a specified.
wire carrying the current at a high voltage from the power source to the electrical appliance.
wire completing the circuit by carrying current back to the power source, maintaining a low potential close to zero volts.
The amount of thermal energy absorbed or emitted by a substance per unit temperature change
total kinetic energy and total potential energy of particles in a system
amount of energy transferred to change the state of a substance at constant temperature.
The amount of thermal energy absorbed or emitted by a substance per unit mass per unit temperature change

term: Specific latent heat of fusion, lf
definition: amount of energy transferred per unit mass of a substance to change be- tween the solid and liquid states at constant temperature.

term: Specific latent heat of vaporisation, lv
definition: amount of energy transferred per unit mass of a substance to change between the liquid and gaseous states at constant temperature.
amount of energy transferred per unit mass of a substance to change its state at con- stant temperature. L = ml
ionizing radiation present in the environment
time taken for half of the radioactive atoms in a sample to undergo radioactive decay.
a nuclear reaction in which two or more atomic nuclei combine to form a single, more massive nucleus, along with the release of a significant amount of energy.
atoms of the same element that have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.
a random and spontaneous process whereby an unstable nucleus loses energy by emitting radiation
the sum of number of protons and neutrons in a nucleus
a species of an atom consisting of a particular number of protons and neutrons
a nuclear reaction in which the nucleus of an atom splits into two or more smaller nuclei, along with the release of a significant amount of energy.
